title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the category of crops that has the highest average total energy-based expenses as cotton and rice.
The response identifies the category of crops that has the highest average total energy-based expenses as cotton and rice.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the category with the greatest energy-based expense in poultry farming as electricity.
The response identifies the category with the greatest energy-based expense in poultry farming as electricity.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why there is a difference in fertilizer costs between hog production and corn farming, such as any of the following:

· Corn farming requires large amounts of fertilizer to promote plant growth. Hog farms purchase corn/feed from others, and therefore use less fertilizer.

· Hog farming generates manure that can be used to help grow feed, so less fertilizer has to be purchased.

The response explains why there is a difference in fertilizer costs between hog production and corn farming, such as one of the following:

· Corn farming requires large amounts of fertilizer to promote plant growth. Hog farms purchase corn/feed from others, and therefore use less fertilizer.

· Hog farming generates manure that can be used to help grow feed, so less fertilizer has to be purchased.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem associated with the energy-based expense that is the second highest in the production of cotton and rice, such as any of the following:

· Runoff of excess fertilizer into nearby waterways leads to eutrophication.

· Fertilizer could leach into ground, contaminating drinking water with nitrates.

· Excessive fertilizer/nitrogen can have toxic effects on soil organisms/disrupt nitrogen cycle.

· Excessive fertilizer can lead to soil acidification and cause chemical burns to crops.

· Fertilizer increases the growth of weeds that could compete with corn crops.

The response describes one environmental problem associated with the energy-based expense that is the second highest in the production of cotton and rice, such as one of the following:

· Runoff of excess fertilizer into nearby waterways leads to eutrophication.

· Fertilizer could leach into ground, contaminating drinking water with nitrates.

· Excessive fertilizer/nitrogen can have toxic effects on soil organisms/disrupt nitrogen cycle.

· Excessive fertilizer can lead to soil acidification and cause chemical burns to crops.

· Fertilizer increases the growth of weeds that could compete with corn crops.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a shift from a monoculture of corn to a polyculture of corn, soybeans, and wheat will affect the ecological footprint of the farm, such as any of the following:

· Polyculture crops work together to balance the nutrients in the soil. Some crops add nitrogen to the soil, and some take nitrogen from the soil. This means the farmer wouldn't need to use as much fertilizer on the farm, reducing the ecological footprint.

· Polycultures improve nutrient cycling requiring less fertilizer, which reduces run-off of nitrates and phosphates, reducing the ecological footprint.

· Polycultures increase soil cover that can reduce soil erosion/evaporation and reduce irrigation, thereby reducing the ecological footprint.

The response explains how a shift from a monoculture of corn to a polyculture of corn, soybeans, and wheat will affect the ecological footprint of the farm, such as one of the following:

· Polyculture crops work together to balance the nutrients in the soil. Some crops add nitrogen to the soil, and some take nitrogen from the soil. This means the farmer wouldn't need to use as much fertilizer on the farm, reducing the ecological footprint.

· Polycultures improve nutrient cycling requiring less fertilizer, which reduces run-off of nitrates and phosphates, reducing the ecological footprint.

· Polycultures increase soil cover that can reduce soil erosion/evaporation and reduce irrigation, thereby reducing the ecological footprint.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a poultry farmer installing a wind turbine at the farm would or would not be an effective long-term approach for reducing energy costs, such as any of the following:

· This would be an effective long-term approach. Based on the graph, more than half of the energy-based expenses at the poultry farm are from electricity, so this could be a long-term solution to reduce electrical costs.

· It would not be an effective long-term approach. The poultry farmer could be in an area that does not have sufficient winds to provide enough energy to be a good long-term solution to reduce costs and offset installation and ongoing maintenance costs.

The response explains why a poultry farmer installing a wind turbine at the farm would or would not be an effective long-term approach for reducing energy costs, such as one of the following:

· This would be an effective long-term approach. Based on the graph, more than half of the energy-based expenses at the poultry farm are from electricity, so this could be a long-term solution to reduce electrical costs.

· It would not be an effective long-term approach. The poultry farmer could be in an area that does not have sufficient winds to provide enough energy to be a good long-term solution to reduce costs and offset installation and ongoing maintenance costs.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how conservation landscaping techniques can reduce outdoor watering costs, such as any of the following:

· Planting native/more drought tolerant species for landscaping reduces the need for supplemental watering since the native plants are better adapted to the local climate.

· Cover landscaped areas in mulch or add soil amendments that reduce evaporative water loss from soils surrounding trees and other landscaped vegetation.

The response describes how conservation landscaping techniques can reduce outdoor watering costs, such as one of the following:

· Planting native/more drought tolerant species for landscaping reduces the need for supplemental watering since the native plants are better adapted to the local climate.

· Cover landscaped areas in mulch or add soil amendments that reduce evaporative water loss from soils surrounding trees and other landscaped vegetation.

title: Part H

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one variable not mentioned in the description above that could affect the results of the investigation, such as any of the following:

· Initial size, age, or sex distribution of hogs in each group

· Amount of water provided to each group of hogs

· Diseases/infections that would be more common at higher temperatures

· Genetic variability/different breeds of hogs used

· Varying weather conditions that might reduce appetite (e.g. humidity)

· Pen conditions hogs are kept in/housed in

· Activity level of hogs in each group

· Initial health of hogs in each group

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the farmer will not see maximum lean growth rate in the hogs if the farmer feeds the hogs 2,500 grams of food per day and keeps the hogs outside with average summer temperatures above 30 °C MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaaa baaaaaaaaapeGaaeiSaiaaboeaaaa@3A12@ , such as any of the following:

· The data show that hogs consume less food at higher temperatures, so at 30 °C MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaaa baaaaaaaaapeGaaeiSaiaaboeaaaa@3A12@ the hogs would likely not consume all 2,500 grams of food per day and will not reach their maximum lean growth rate.

· The farmer is feeding the hogs too much food for the hot temperatures and the feed intake should be reduced (to reduce heat production associated with digestion/metabolism) to increase lean growth rate.
